content.text: One of a group of three students is to be chosen at random.
Explain how a single throw of a fair six-sided dice could be used to make the choice.
The times, in minutes, taken by students to complete a test are normally distributed with mean 125 and variance 50. Two students are chosen at random.
Find the probability that the difference between the times taken by these two students to complete the test is more than 12 minutes.
The height of a certain species of plant is denoted by \(H \mathrm{~cm}\). The heights of a random sample of 100 plants were measured, and the following results were found.
• The mean, \(\bar{h}\), for the sample was 80.2.
• An unbiased estimate of the population variance of \(H\) was 15.6.
Write down an expression in terms of e for \(\mathrm{P}(X=12)\).
Write down an equation in \(n\), and hence find the value of \(n\).
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\operatorname{Po}(15)\).

A biased spinner has four sides. Each side is of a different colour: yellow, red, green or black. The probability, \(p\), that the spinner will land on red is unknown. The spinner was spun 200 times, and the proportion, \(a\), of times that it landed on red was noted. This proportion was used to calculate an approximate \(90 \%\) confidence interval for \(p\). The width of this confidence interval was 0.1066 correct to 4 significant figures.
Find the two possible values of \(a\).

The amount of time, in minutes, spent by a customer on one visit to a certain shop is modelled by the random variable \(X \sim \mathrm{N}(\mu, \sigma^{2})\). In the past, the values of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\) were 10.5 and 3.8 respectively. The shop has recently moved to a new location, and the manager hopes that the new value of \(\mu\) will be greater than 10.5. He takes a random sample of 10 customers and notes the time they each spend in the shop. He then calculates the sample mean \(\bar{x}\) for these 10 times.
Using a hypothesis test at the \(5 \%\) significance level, the manager finds that there is sufficient evidence to conclude that the new value of \(\mu\) is greater than 10.5.
Stating a necessary assumption, find the smallest possible value of \(\bar{x}\).
Two values of \(W\) are chosen at random.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.
The random variable \(W\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}(700,0.005)\).
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(X>205)\).
Use suitable approximating distributions to answer the following.
The random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by
Use a binomial distribution with a \(5\%\) significance level to test Birgitte's suspicion. [5]
Calculate the probability of a Type I error.
Given that the value of \(p\) is actually 0.02, calculate the probability of a Type II error.

Birgitte has a six-sided dice. She suspects that the dice is biased so that the probability, \(p\), that it will show a six on one throw is less than \(\frac{1}{6}\). She throws the dice 30 times and finds that it shows a six on exactly 2 throws.
